column1: What is SVN?
column2: SVN or Subversion is an open source code control system. It is used to trace all the changes made to your source code or files.  It is a repository used to manage files
column3: folders
column4: directories and the modification made to these files over a period of time.

column1: What is the difference between GIT and SVN repository?
column2: The difference between SVN and GIT is
column3: Git does not support commits across multiple branches or tags. Subversion allows the creation of folders at any location in the repository layout. Gits are unchangeable while subversion enables committers to treat a tag a branch and to create multiple revisions under a tag root. Git is less preferred for handling large files or frequently changing binary files while SVN is capable of handling multiple projects stored in the same repository.

column1: List out what all things should be stored in the SVN repository?
column2: Source Code
column3: Build scripts
column6: Project settings (When the whole team is using the same IDE)
column12: And other documents related to the project.

column1: What is the command to add a file or dir?
column2: svn add filename and svn add dirname

column1: List out the common subversion commands?
column2: Import. Checkout. Commit. Update.

column1: What is the difference between commit and update?
column2: Update is used to update the local workspace with the changes made by the team to the repository
column3: while commit is the process to implement changes from local to repository
column5: upload a file into the repository.

column1: Explain how you can apply a patch in SVN?
column2: To apply a patch in SVN
column3: you are required to Create Patch by making changes and generating the .diff file.  Then this .diff file can be implemented to the new code base using Apply Patch.

column1: What is the command to create a new directory under version control?
column2: svn mkdir directory
column3: svn mkdir http://url/directory.

column1: How you can import your existing directory into the new repository?
column2: The command you will use to import your existing directory into the new repository you have to write
column3: svn import/home/mysurface/programming file:///home/mysurface/repo/programing_repo-m initial import.

column1: What is the command to see what is inside the repository?
column2: Command svn list file:///home/mysurface/repo/programming_repo is used to see what is inside the repository.

column1: What is the command to view the difference between the local version and repository version?
column2: The command used to view the difference between the local and repository version is
column3: svn diff filename

column1: Mention what does the result codes G and R in svn indicates?
column2: The result codes G and R in svn indicates
column3: G code: Changes on the repo were automatically merged into the working copy
column4: R code: This code indicates that the item has been replaced in your working copy. This means the file was programmed or scheduled for deletion
column5: and a new file with the same name was scheduled for addition in its place.

column1: Mention what is the function of Revert in subversion?
column2: Revert function will remove your local changes and reload the latest version from the repository.

column1: Explain how you can revert to a previous version?
column2: To retrieve a previous version
column3: you have to use revert command. But revert command will simply erase local edits
column4: what you actually need is to merge command. For example
column5: you have a file [abc.txt] and the current version is 101
column6: and you want version 201. Then you will use the command like svn merge r 101:201 abc.txt svn commit m Reverted to revision 201 abc.txt

column1: Which commands can be used to move some subset of code and history of this code from one SVN repo to another?
column2: Following commands can be used svnadmin dump svndumpfilter include svnadmin load svn remove.

column1: List out what is the best practices for SVN?
column2: Update and Test before commit Work from your own local workspace Commit small autonomous changes Validate the files you are committing
column3: you actually changed Keep in touch with repository Watch for conflicts Always group your check-in logically Use comment

column1: Explain what checkout command is and how to use the checkout command in SVN?
column2: Check-Out command in SVN is used to create a local workable copy of your project retrieved from the local repository. For example
column3: you have a project located in the repository created at URL location http://www.guru99.com/svn/myrepo/myproject.  So you have to checkout myproject into your local system assuming myrepo is a public repository. You will use code. svn co http://www.guru99.com/svn/myrepo/myproject . This command will copy all your files to your current directory. If you want checkout the directory which is in a private repository
column4: you will then use the following command svn co http://www.guru99.com/svn/privaterepo/myproject username admin password admin.

column1: Explain the terminologies trunk batch and tag?
column2: Trunk: it is a mainstream of development present in SVN repository created at the start and exists till the end of a project. Branch: it is copy derived from a trunk. It flows in direction of certain changes without disturbing other users. Multiple branches can be created each having its own path of code changes for different functionalities. Tag: display milestones in the repository history section
column3: where major changes are done or points where code revision is done.

column1: Why revert command is used in subversion?
column2: Local Revert: it removes the changes done recently that are done after update command is run and before those changes are committed in a repository. Repo Revert: it removes changes done on a repository level.

column1: How to check the content of a repository?
column2: In SVN you can see the tree structure of all the directories
column3: folders
column4: files present under any given repository. There are subversion commands that help in this.

column1: Is it possible to add a file directly in the repository ?
column2: Yes
column3: the same is possible and the users can go ahead with the command svn add filename and svn add dirname

column1: Can you tell how in Subversion
column2: how the command commit can be put separated from the command update?
column3: When it comes to updating the local workspace
column4: the command which is used often is Update. It reflects all the modifications made to the document by any member of the team. On the other side
column5: the Commit make sure to implement properly the same modifications made to the data from present location to the repository. It can also be said that it simply upload the files and the documents in the repository without making the users to made any sort of efforts.

column1: Why do you think there is a need to made changes to the files
column2: documents or the source codes in businesses?
column3: business management is itself a very vast term. There are tasks and decisions that are properly based on data and information. When it comes to executing them
column4: businesses often test them in different manners. The reports are generated accordingly and the new outcomes achieved are often considered and is clubbed with the existing information. Thus
column6: files and source code are frequent. In other words
column7: any sort of changes are made because of no other reason but the betterment of the business.

column1: In Subversion
column2: is it possible for the users to apply a patch directly in a subsection without taking the entire document into consideration?
column3: The same is possible and there are certain methods to keep up the pace for this. The users are always in a position to get the things done in the shortest possible time. On the best methods for this is to create a patch. This can be done with the help of .diff file The same can then be considered in the new code base and the user are free to make use of the command Apply Patch for this.

column1: Suppose you need to verify what exactly is present inside a repository
column2: how you will do this?
column3: Execute the following command for this. ".svn list file"

column1: How the file from the svn repo can be erased?
column2: .svn delete filename

column1: By making use of a single command
column2: can you list the entire COS in SVN?
column3: Yes
column4: there are some dedicated commands available for the same. One that you can execute is "Ct lsco-me".

column1: Why is JIRA used?
column2: Atlassian JIRA is basically an issue and project tracking tool which allows us to track any project related work by following a proper workflow.

column1: Explain JIRA workflow?
column2: The workflow here includes the creation of an issue
column3: series of actions performed to fix the issue and the last step includes the closing or say completion of the issue after verification.

column1: Enlist the report types generated by JIRA?
column2: Average Age Report
column3: Created vs Resolved issue Report

column1: Explain the step by step procedure of how an issue is created in JIRA?
column2: Log in to your JIRA account by using valid credentials and get directed to the dashboard. Click on Create button displayed and you will be navigated to a window for creating an issue. Enter all the necessary details as required to create an issue.

column1: Explain the three color indicators and their significance in JIRA ?
column2: For any particular issue in JIRA
column3: 3 colors like Blue
column4: Green and Orange is used to denote the amount of time spent on any particular issue. Blue denote the Original Estimate
column5: Orange determines the time left for resolving
column6: Green defines the actual time that has been used.

column1: For any particular issue in JIRA
column2: what all are included under change history?
column3: Creation and deletion of a comment. Creation and deletion of an issue link. Deletion of a worklog. File attachment changes. Issue field changes

column1: Mention a way with which an issue can be shared with other users in JIRA ?
column2: An issue can be shared with other users in JIRA by using the share option available on the issue description page.

column1: What is the importance of labeling issue in JIRA?
column2: Labeling an issue is basically done to categorize an issue within a particular section which in turn can be easily searched with the help of labels.

column1: How is an issue linked in JIRA?
column2: There are two fields available in JIRA: Linked issues and Issues. Linked issue section contains the dropdown for the options to be selected as the reason for linking the issue.

column1: What is the purpose of JIRA dashboard?
column2: The first page which is displayed whenever we get logged in to JIRA application is Dashboard which is basically the default or system dashboard.

column1: What do you mean by Scheduling an issue in JIRA?
column2: Scheduling the issue means scheduling the work of issue for a particular due date.

column1: Explain how particular project details are listed in JIRA ?
column2: Every project has some main attributes which have to be displayed in the project summary. This includes Name
column3: key

column1: What are issues types that are created and tracked via JIRA?
column2: JIRA has some defined set of default issue types which are displayed under Issue Type section. Other issue types can be added
column3: edited and deleted as per requirement of the project. Some of the common issue types are Bug

column1: How is a sub-task created in JIRA?
column2: Sub-task is the way of splitting up of parent issue into a number of small tasks which are tracked and worked on separately.

column1: Explain the term Cloning an issue in JIRA ?
column2: Cloning an issue means copying an issue.

column1: Explain Kanban boar in JIRA?
column2: Kanban boards are created for the projects where the team has their prime focus on visualizing the workflow and managing the projects work in progress.

column1: Mention one similarity and one difference between JIRA Scrum and JIRA Kanban?
column2: Both JIRA Scrum and Kanban is considered as the most powerful process tool for optimization of work and the processes as both processes focus is on continuous optimization and visualizing the workflow.  Scrum board is the work mode where progress of sprints and tracking of its work is done. Here the team determines the list of issues that has become backlog and then these issues are moved to sprints as per team plan.

column1: What are the most useful JIRA add-ons?
column2: Jenkins-CI
column3: Usersnap

column1: What comes under JIRA Schema?
column2: Workflows
column3: Issue types

column1: How is security setting helpful in JIRA? Security setting for any issue is defined or say set either at the time of creation of the issue or while editing the issue.
A short note on JIRA reports?
column2: JIRA withholds a classified list of reports to depict the project statistics to the user.

column1: What is Jira Core and its uses and who are Jira core project administrators?
column2: It is an efficient workflow management system which allows formulating unique process. this utility allows to both increase and decreases the complexity of the workflows. this allows implying more importance on the process involved.

column1: Can an Issue be assigned to two different people
column2: Explain Cloning issue
column3: then what are linked issues?
column4: JIRA does not support assignation of the same issue under two different people at the same instance of time. this maintains the stability that one multiple developer can never be tagged to the same issue ever. But at several instances based on the intensity and volume of work the issue or bug may generate there could be a possibility of tagging more than one resources to the same issue.

column1: Adding Gadgets to JIRA dashboard?
column2: Several gadgets can be added to JIRA personal dashboards. The JIRA admin is responsible for adding a gadget to a default dashboard of a JIRA application.
